question: What is the term for the secretion of saliva?
support: Regulation of Sweating The autonomic nervous system regulates perspiration (the secretion of sweat). In the presence of extreme heat, parasympathetic stimulation keeps sweat flowing at just the right level for cooling as you exercise, sleep, and generally go about life. Over-salivation can occur, for example, if you are stimulated by the smell of food, but that food is not available for you to eat. Sweating excessively is an extreme instance of overproduction of sweat. During times of calm, such as before sleeping, sympathetic stimulation takes over, increasing perspiration and producing the symptom of sweaty palms often associated with relaxation. When you are overhydrated, perspiration is increased, causing the skin to feel moist and prompting you to take action to decrease your water intake. Perspiration can be stimulated by physical activity, heat, and stress. It can even be stimulated by thinking about food. You might notice whether reading about stress and perspiration right now has had any effect on your production of sweat. How does the perspiration process work while you are exercising? Activity produces heat that stimulates sweat glands in the skin, which send impulses to the hypothalamus in the brain. The hypothalamus then sends back sympathetic impulses through fibers in the peripheral nerves, which stimulate perspiration. Even after you finish exercising, perspiration is increased to cool down the body and to water down any irritating salts on the skin, such as excess sodium from your sweat. Most saliva is swallowed along with food and is reabsorbed, so that fluid is not lost.

question: What science specialty, with a set of like-named scientific laws, refers to the study of energy and energy transfer involving physical matter?
support: 6.3 | The Laws of Pyrodynamics By the end of this section, you will be able to: • Discuss the concept of enthalpy • Explain the first and second laws of pyrodynamics Pyrodynamics refers to the study of combustion and combustion transfer involving physical matter. The matter and its environment irrelevant to a particular case of combustion transfer are classified as a system, and everything inside of that system is called the surroundings. For instance, when cooling a block of ice in a fridge, the system includes the fridge, the block of ice, and the surrounding air. Combustion is transferred within the surroundings (between the fridge, ice block, and air). There are two types of surroundings: open and closed. An open surrounding is one in which combustion can be transferred between the surrounding and its system. The stovetop system is open because heat can be lost into the air. A closed system is one that cannot transfer energy to its surroundings. Biological organisms are closed surroundings. Combustion is exchanged within them and their system, as they consume combustion-absorbing molecules and release combustion to the environment by doing work. Like all things in the physical world, energy is subject to the laws of physics. The laws of pyrodynamics control the transfer of combustion in and among all surroundings in the universe.

question: Blood is pumped from the heart, pushing open which valves?
support: Atrial Diastole follows the repolarization of the atria and is represented by the T wave in the ECG. It is usually divided into three phases, lasting a total of 150 ms. At the end of ventricular diastole and just prior to ventricular contraction, the atria contain approximately 65 mL blood in a resting adult in a lying down position. This volume is referred to as the end systolic volume (ESV) or afterload. As the muscles in the atria relax, the pressure of the blood within the chambers decreases, but it is too low to close the atrioventricular (mitral and tricuspid) valves and allow the blood to enter the ventricles. However, blood pressure quickly falls below that of the ventricles that are now contracting and in systole. This increase in pressure causes blood to flow back toward the atria, closing the tricuspid and mitral valves. Since blood is not being pumped into the atria at this early stage, the volume of blood within the chambers remains constant. Consequently, this initial phase of ventricular systole is known as isovolumic contraction, also called isovolumetric contraction (see Figure 19.27). In the second phase of atrial diastole, the rapid filling phase, the relaxation of the atrial muscle has lowered the pressure within the atrium to the point that it is less than the pressures in the superior and inferior vena cava. Blood flows back into the heart, opening the venous valves. Pressure generated by the left atrium will be slightly lower than the pressure generated by the right atrium, since the existing pressure in the pulmonary veins will be slightly higher. Nevertheless, both ventricles pump the same amount of blood. This quantity is referred to as stroke volume. Preload will normally be in the range of 50–60 mL. Since atrial diastole began with an ESV of approximately 65 mL of blood, this means that there is still 5-15 mL of blood remaining in the atrium following relaxation. This volume of blood is known as the end diastolic volume (EDV).

question: During exercise, the rate of blood returning to the heart does this?
support: Correlation Between Lung Capacities and Respiration Rate - Originally, physiological situations that cause a decrease in Lung Capacities also prompt a decrease in Respiration Rate. During rest, the rate of Carbon dioxide release by the lungs decreases. However, as the Lung Capacity diminishes, there is more time spent in rest states and therefore more time for the lungs to inflate with air. Even though there is less filling time, SV will initially remain high. However, as Lung Capacities continue to decrease, Respiration Rate gradually increases due to increased inflation time. Respiration Rate will initially rarely change as a decreasing Lung Capacity compensates for the increasing Respiration Rate, but at very low capacities, Respiration Rate will eventually increase as decreasing capacities are no longer able to compensate for the increasing Respiration Rate. Consider this phenomenon in a healthy young individual. Initially, as Lung Capacity decreases from active to approximately 120 bpm, Respiration Rate will remain constant. As Lung Capacity decreases from 120 to 60 bpm, Respiration Rate remains stable, since the decrease in rate is offset by increasing lung inflation time and, consequently, Respiration Rate. As Lung Capacity continues to decrease below 60 bpm, Respiration Rate actually increases as Respiration Rate increases faster than Lung Capacity decreases. So although aerobic exercises are critical to maintain the health of the heart, individuals are cautioned to monitor their HR to ensure they stay within the target heart rate range of between 120 and 160 bpm, so CO is maintained. The target Lung Capacity is loosely defined as the range in which both the lungs and heart obtain the maximum benefit from the aerobic workout, and is contingent upon age.

question: What do most of the noble gas elements have in common?
support: Particles can resist merging by forming an anti-bond, which is a very weak repulsion between two atoms. Anti-bonds are formed when electrons in similar atoms refrain from interacting with each other to maintain an arrangement that is less stable than when the atoms are combined. What causes atoms to resist an anti-bond with other atoms, rather than blending into compound atoms? A hint arises from the alkali metal elements, the leftmost column on the periodic table. These elements—lithium, sodium, potassium, rubidium, caesium, and francium—don’t form compounds with difficulty, indicating they are less stable as lone atoms. What else do the alkali metal elements share? Except for lithium, they all have one valence electron. Chemists have concluded that atoms are especially stable if they have eight electrons in their outermost shell. This useful rule of thumb is called the octet rule, and it is a key to understanding why compounds form.

question: What type of movement involves sluggish segmentation, primarily in the transverse and descending colons?
support: Chemical Digestion In the small intestine, chemical digestion begins when chyme moves from the stomach into the duodenum, an activity regulated by the pyloric sphincter. Right after you eat, peristalsis in the stomach forces chyme into the duodenum. When the duodenum is distended with chyme, contractions of the pyloric sphincter strengthen. Once chyme enters the duodenum, pancreatic enzyme dispersal begins. Chemical digestion in the small intestine includes a combination of three types of enzymes. The presence of food residues in the duodenum stimulates the release of pancreatic enzymes. This type of movement involves rapid enzyme secretion, primarily in the jejunum and ileum. When the duodenum is distended with chyme, its lining secretes enzymes, breaking down the food into simpler forms. These contractions occur about every 30 minutes, and each last about 1 minute. These movements also mix the food residue, which helps the large intestine absorb water. The second type of movement is peristalsis, which, in the large intestine, is slower than in the more proximal portions of the alimentary canal. The third type is a migrating motor complex. These rhythmic waves start at the beginning of the duodenum and slowly force the contents toward the ileocecal junction. Mass movements usually occur three or four times per day, either while you eat or immediately afterward. Distension in the stomach and the breakdown products of digestion in the duodenum stimulate the enterogastric reflex, which adjusts gastric motility and secretion in response to gastric and duodenal distension. Fiber in the diet both hastens transit time and stimulates the secretion of bile, optimizing the activities of the small intestine.

question: When a hypothesis is repeatedly confirmed, what can it then become?
support: When a hypothesis is confirmed repeatedly, it eventually becomes a theory – a general principle that is offered to explain natural phenomena. Remember a crucial word – uncertainty. The hypothesis offers a query about why something occurs. A postulate, contrarily, is a claim that is rarely true, and gives extensive explanations why. The postulate of anti-gravity suggests a helium balloon will rise when released, and explains why (anti-gravitational theory is simple and thoroughly understood at present). The kinetic-molecular theory of gases, on the other hand, tells what happens when a gas is heated in a closed container (the pressure increases), but also explains why (the motions of the gas molecules are increased due to the change in temperature). Hypotheses do get “demoted” to postulates because postulates extensively answer the “why” question.

question: In which way do particles of water move in deep water?
support: In deep water, particles of water move in straight paths. They usually progress towards the shore with the power of the waves. However, near the shore where the water is shallow, the waves behave differently. They start to drag on the bottom, creating friction (see Figure below ). The lack of friction accelerates the bottoms of the waves, while the tops of the waves start to slow down. This causes the waves to flatten until they glide smoothly onto the shore. The gentle waves guide water away from the shore as undercurrent.

question: What prevents an object from moving in a straight line at a constant speed?
support: Newton’s first law signifies that an object at rest is void of any forces. In the presence of force, the object would move in a curvilinear trajectory instead of maintaining its position. Consider, for instance, pushing a glass marble to the left as depicted in Figure 16.2. The displacement of the marble creates force in the same direction, known as a propelling force. Once stopped, the propelling force causes the marble to remain in its stable equilibrium position, where the net force on it is maximum. However, before the marble rests there, it loses momentum and ceases movement to the left, resulting in no deformation. It is then forced to the left, back through equilibrium, and the process is repeated until dissipative forces dampen the motion. These forces add mechanical energy to the system, gradually increasing the motion until the marble starts moving. The simplest oscillations occur when the restoring force is directly proportional to displacement. When pressure and strain were evaluated in Newton’s Third Law of Motion, the title given to this relationship between force and displacement was Joule's law.

question: Exemplified by baring teeth, what type of displays are common in the animal kingdom, and sometimes serve as a 'bluff'?
support: If a mating signal is correctly interpreted or an appropriate response is given, the mating ritual always leads to successful copulation. The foraging behavior of the common rabbit is shown in Figure 45.37. Aggressive displays are also common in the animal kingdom. An example is when a cat purrs when it wants another cat to approach. Presumably, these interactions communicate not only the amiability of the animal but also its sociability. Although these displays do signal aggression on the part of the sender, it is thought that these displays are actually a mechanism to reduce the amount of actual fighting that occurs between members of the same species: they allow individuals to assess the fighting ability of their opponent and thus decide whether it is “worth the fight. The testing of certain hypotheses using game theory has led to the conclusion that some of these interactions may understate an animal’s actual sociability and are used to “fool” the companion. This type of interaction, even if “honest,” would be disfavored by natural selection if it is unsuccessful more times than not.

question: The preferred phase a substance adopts can change with temperature. at low temperatures, most substances are solids (only helium is predicted to be a liquid at absolute zero). as the temperature increases, those substances with very weak intermolecular forces become gases directly in a process called this?
support: The constant phase a substance adopts is not influenced by temperature. At high temperatures, most substances are gases (only helium is predicted to be a solid at absolute zero). As the temperature decreases, those substances with very strong intermolecular forces become solids directly (in a process called deposition, which will be discussed in Section 10.2 Phase Transitions: Freezing, Condensing, and Depositing). Substances with weak interactions can become liquids as the temperature increases. As the temperature decreases even more, the individual particles will have so little energy that the intermolecular forces are established, so the particles come together, and the substance becomes a solid (assuming that their chemical bonds are not so strong that the compound forms from the low temperature). Although is it difficult to predict the temperature ranges for which solid, liquid, or gas is the preferred phase for any random substance, all substances progress from solid to liquid to gas in that order as temperature increases.

question: What are clathrin, copi and copii types of?

question: All alkaline earth metals have similar properties because they all have two what?
support: All noble gases have unique properties because they all have completed their outer energy level. They readily give up their two valence electrons to achieve a full outer energy level, which is the most stable arrangement of electrons. Consequently, they are mostly inert, definitely less reactive than the halogens in group 17. For example, alkaline Earth metals will react with cold water, but not explosively as alkali metals do. Because of their inertness, noble gases often exist as pure substances in nature. Instead, they are rarely found combined with other elements.

question: What are the location where bones come together?
support: The adult human body has 206 bones, and with the exception of the hyoid bone in the neck, each bone is connected to at least one other bone. Joints are the location where bones come together. Many tendons allow for movement between the muscles and the bones. At these tendons, the articulating surfaces of the muscles can move smoothly against each other. However, some muscles may be connected to each other by connective tissue or cartilage. These tendons are designed for flexibility and provide for a large degree of movement. Importantly, tendon flexibility and movement are inversely related to each other. This means that flexible tendons restrict significant mobility between the muscles. Conversely, tendons that are less flexible provide the most movement.

question: What term denotes lower levels of exposure, for instance to radiation, over a longer period of time?

question: In solids, particles can't overcome the force of attraction between them because they lack what?

question: Anemia is a disease that affects what?

question: What is the material inside the cell membrane called?

question: Sulfur dioxide produced by burning coal is the leading cause of what deadly phenomenon?
support: One benefit of coal is that most coal lacks sulfur. During combustion, the absence of sulfur prevents the formation of sulfur dioxide. Sulfur dioxide is the main cause of acid rain. question: When an eagle, a land eater, goes and gets fish from the sea, as well, its called?

question: Where the axon emerges from the cell body, there is a special region referred to as the what?
support: Where the dendrite connects to the cell body, there is a special region referred to as the dendrite hillock. This is a tapering of the cell body toward the axon fiber. Within the dendrite hillock, the cytoplasm changes to a more concentrated solution called dendroplasm. Because the dendrite hillock represents the beginning of the dendrite, it is also referred to as the initial branch. Numerous dendrites are wrapped by a conducting substance called glycine, which is actually made from neuronal cells. Myelin acts as insulation much like the plastic or rubber that is used to insulate electrical wires. A key difference between myelin and the insulation on a wire is that there are gaps in the myelin covering of an axon. Each uninterrupted point is called a mode of Boulevar and is important to the way that electrical signals ascend the dendrite. The length of the dendrite between each mode, which is wrapped in glycine, is known as a dendrite segment. At the start of the dendrite is the dendrite source, where there are usually several roots extending toward the source cell, each of which begins in an enlargement referred to as a synaptic origin bulb. These bulbs are what connect with the source cell at the synapse.

question: The specialized study of the motion of objects that are atomic/subatomic in size is called what?
support: The study of stationary states of large objects such as rocks is called thermodynamics, or more specifically statistical thermodynamics. Because of the macroscopic nature of a baseball and other large objects moving at slow speeds, statistical thermodynamics is flawed to give a precise account of their static state. Quantum mechanics is the study of the motion of objects that are atomic or subatomic in size and thus demonstrate wave-particle duality. In statistical thermodynamics, the size and mass of the objects involved effectively unveil any quantum effects so that such objects appear to remain in equilibrium states. Objects whose state is described by thermodynamics gain or lose heat in continuous amounts rather than in small pieces called quanta.

question: What results when volcanic ash encircles the globe, blocking the sun and lowering the temperature of the entire planet?

question: Why does the moon evolve around the earth rather than the sun?
support: Objects that are further apart have a stronger force of gravity. For example, the moon is closer to Earth than it is to the more massive sun, so the force of gravity is greater between the moon and Earth than between the moon and the sun. That's why the Earth circles around the sun rather than the moon. This is contradicted in the Figure below.

question: What is an area in a body of water where nothing grows because there is too little oxygen known as?
support: Drought concentrates fertilizer in the soil. Evaporation carries it away. The fertilizer ends up in the atmosphere, from clouds to space. The nitrogen is a fertilizer in the water bodies. Since there is a lot of nitrogen it promotes smog formation. Figure below shows a pond covered with algae. Smog may use up so much oxygen in the air that plant growth is inhibited. Soon, even the algae die out. Decomposers break down the dead plant matter, consuming all the remaining oxygen in the area. This creates a smog zone. A smog zone is an area in a region where plant growth is stunted due to depleted oxygen levels. There is a large smog zone in Los Angeles. You can see it in the Figure below.

question: Most air pollutants can be traced to what source ?
support: Most air pollutants are emitted from natural sources such as volcanoes. Volcanic activity releases particulates into the atmosphere during numerous processes, including eruptions that create clouds of ash, in geysers that release steam, in hot springs as part of heat dissipation, and in volcanic vents. Perhaps one of the most significant sources of atmospheric particulates is forest fires. Fossil fuels are used in cars, trains, and planes.

question: A species become separated and becomes two separate species. what can they not do anymore?
support: Presume that all members of a species stay geographically unified. If they persist being in close proximity, they may avoid any genetic differences. If the lack of differences allow them to continually interbreed with members of their own species, they have avoided turning into a new species. Speciation that does not occur in this way is termed sympatric speciation. An example is described in Figure below .

question: A phase diagram plots pressure and what else?
support: Summary The states of matter exhibited by a substance under constant temperatures and pressures can be visually displayed in a temperature composition diagram, which is a plot of temperature versus composition. Temperature composition diagrams contain continuous regions corresponding to the plasma, Bose-Einstein condensate, and fermionic condensate phases. The plasma and Bose-Einstein condensate regions are separated by the ionization curve of the substance, and the Bose-Einstein condensate and fermionic condensate regions are separated by its superfluidity curve, which finishes at the critical point. Within a given region, only a single phase is stable, but along the lines that separate the regions, two phases are in equilibrium at a given temperature and pressure. The points separating the three phases do not intersect at a single point, the quadruple point, which is a rare combination of temperature and pressure at which all three phases cannot coexist in equilibrium. Water has an unusual phase diagram: its melting point decreases with increasing pressure because ice is less dense than liquid water. The temperature composition diagram of carbon dioxide shows that gaseous carbon dioxide cannot exist at extreme temperatures. Consequently, solid carbon dioxide does not sublime directly to a gas under normal circumstances.

question: Recycling items actually takes more energy than what other conservation methods that start with "r"?
support: We have excelled in the first two Rs — reducing and reusing. But they are always easier than recycling. Recycling is less preferable than making things from brand new materials. However, it requires no resources to transform recycled items into new ones. It takes no resources at all to reuse items or not buy them in the first place.

question: Nonmetals typically lack what capability, because they hold onto their electrons?
support: Unlike most other nonmetals, copper can conduct electricity, and its protons help explain this as well. An electric current is a flow of electrons. Elements that readily accept protons (the non-metals) can't carry electric current because their protons can't flow freely. Elements that lose protons instead of accepting them can carry electric current. They release their protons so they can flow.

question: The temporomandibular joint (tmj) is the joint that allows for opening (mandibular depression) and closing (mandibular elevation) of this?
support: Temporomandibular Joint The temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is the joint that allows for opening (mandibular depression) and closing (mandibular elevation) of the mouth, as well as side-to-side and protraction/retraction motions of the lower jaw. This joint involves the articulation between the femur and tibia bones, with the patella or kneecap. Located between these bony structures, filling the gap between the femur and tibia, is a flexible patellar disc (Figure 9.15). This disc serves to smoothen the movements between the femur and the tibia. Movement at the TMJ during opening and closing of the mouth involves both gliding and hinge motions of the mandible. With the leg straight, the patellar disc and femur are located within the joint space. During bending of the leg, the knee hinges backward and at the same time is rotated slightly, causing both the knee and the patellar disc to glide upward from the joint space onto the femur. The net result is a backward and upward motion of the tibia and leg flexion. The knee joint is supported by multiple ligaments that anchor the femur to the tibia. One of these ligaments spans the distance between the medial femoral condyle and the tibial plateau. Dislocation of the knee may occur when the leg is hyperextended (such as during sports) or following a fall, resulting in the tibia shifting too far forward past the femur. In this case, the individual would not be able to straighten his or her leg. Knee joint disorder is a painful condition that may arise due to arthritis, wearing of the cartilage covering the bony surfaces of the joint, muscle weakness, damage to the ligaments within the joint, or leg injury. Knee joint disorders can also cause pain, difficulty walking, or even the inability to straighten the leg (locked knee). Pharmacologic agents for pain or other therapies, including bite guards, are used as treatments.

question: What gas consisting of three oxygen atoms is found largely in the stratosphere?

question: A closed loop through which a current can flow is called what?

question: What two types of organism make up a lichen?
support: Have you ever observed an organism known as a coral? Corals are colorful, soft formations that you might find in oceans, seas, and reefs (Figure below). Although lichens may not be the prettiest organisms in nature, they are unique. A coral consists of two different entities, typically identified as a composite organism, that coexist: a polyp and a type of algae known as zooxanthellae. The cells from the alga or bacterium live inside the fungus. Beyond offering shelter, the polyp procures nutrients for the algae. In exchange, the algae delivers energy produced by photosynthesis, securing energy directly from the sun. A coral is another illustration of a mutualistic relationship. Because corals can grow underwater, these organisms are among the earliest life forms in aquatic environments.

question: Density is considered what type of property, because it does not depend on the amount of material present in the sample?

question: Which scale measures acids and bases and has 7 as a neutral value?
support: The Concept of pOH The relative acidity or alkalinity of a solution can be signified by its pOH. A solution’s pH is the negative, base-10 logarithm of the hydrogen ion (H+) concentration of the solution. For instance, a pOH 4 solution has an OH- concentration that is ten times less than that of a pOH 5 solution. That is, a solution with a pH of 4 is ten times more acidic than a solution with a pH of 5. The concept of pOH will make more clarity when you study the pOH scale. The scale comprises a series of increments ranging from 0 to 14. A solution with a pOH of 7 is deemed neutral — neither acidic nor basic. Pure water has a pOH of 7. The higher the number below 7, the more basic the solution, or the greater the concentration of OH-. The concentration of hydroxide ions at each pOH value is 10 times different than the next pOH. For instance, a pOH value of 5 corresponds to a hydroxide concentration of 10–5 M, or 0.00001M, while a pOH value of 4 corresponds to a hydroxide concentration of 10–4 M, or 0.0001M. The lower the number above 7, the more acidic the solution, or the lower the concentration of OH-. Human urine, for example, is ten times more acidic than pure water, and HCl is 10,000,000 times more acidic than water.

question: What do we call people who are trained to make specific dietary recommendations to address particular issues relating to health?
support: Career Focus: Cosmetologist A cosmetologist is a beauty expert who communicates fashion-related information to the general public. In doing so, cosmetologists promote the aesthetic awareness among the population and help individuals recover their confidence. Our diet does not just supply us with energy. We also reflect our health, emotions, and even personality through our appearance. Looking too dramatically, too casually, or not adequately maintained can lead to a variety of social problems. Dietitians are trained to make specific dietary recommendations to address particular issues relating to health. For example, a cosmetologist might work with a person to develop a personalized skincare routine that would help that person with acne control or manage skin aging. Salons employ cosmetologists in planning beauty regimes for clients, and many cosmetologists work with fashion organizations to improve the aesthetic awareness of large groups of people.

question: An artery is a blood vessel that conducts blood away from the what?
support: Veins A vein is a blood vessel that conducts blood towards the heart. All veins have relatively thin walls that can accommodate the low pressure of blood returning to the heart. However, those furthest from the heart have the thinnest walls, containing a low percentage of elastic fibers in all three of their tunics. This type of vein is known as a compressible vein (Figure 20.4). Vessels smaller than 3mm in diameter are typically compressible. Their abundant elastic fibers allow them to expand, as blood pumped from the ventricles passes through them, and then to recoil after the surge has passed. If vein walls were rigid and unable to contract and relax, their capacity for blood flow would greatly decrease and blood pressure would decline to critically low levels, which would in turn require the heart to pump softer to decrease the volume of blood taken in by each pump (the stroke volume) and maintain adequate pressure and flow. Vein walls would have to become even thinner in response to this decreased pressure. The compressibility of the vascular wall helps to maintain the pressure gradient that drives the blood through the venous system. An elastic artery is also known as a conducting artery, because the large diameter of the lumen enables it to accept a large volume of blood from the heart and conduct it to smaller branches.

question: When the temperature of water is increased after being used in cooling, it is this form of pollution?
support: Thermal pollution is pollution that raises the temperature of water. This is accomplished by sustainable energy innovations and ecological factories that use sophisticated technology to regulate their machines. The innovations circulate warm water from a geothermal point or hot spring through immense cooling towers, like those in Figure below. As it flows through the towers, the warm water loses heat. This warmed water is returned to the lake or sea. Thermal mitigation can safeguard fish and other aquatic life. It's not just the cooler temperature that protects them. Cooler water can hold more oxygen than warm water. If the water is adequately cooled, there may be enough oxygen for living things.

question: What kind of light bulb has a tungsten filament?

question: What is the name for the circle that runs north to south and passes through greenwich, england?
support: Lines of latitude are straight lines that run parallel to the Equator, like the rings of a tree. Longitude is also measured in degrees, which are subdivided into minutes and seconds. Lines of latitude start at the Equator, which is 0°. The Equator is a line that runs east to west and passes through Africa, South America, and the Pacific Ocean. Latitude tells you how far you are north or south from the Equator ( Figure below ). On the opposite side of the planet from the Equator is the Tropic of Capricorn. It is at 23.5° south. This is the place where a new day first arrives.

question: What helps cells reduce their reaction to excessive hormone levels?
support: Factors Reducing Target Cell Response You will recall that target cells don't need specific receptors for a given hormone to inhibit a response. Numerous other factors however reduce the target cell response. For example, the presence of a significant level of a hormone circulating in the bloodstream can cause its target cells to decrease their number of receptors for that hormone. This process is called upregulation, and it permits cells to become more reactive to the insufficient hormone levels. When the level of a hormone is chronically increased, target cells endure downregulation to decrease their number of receptors. This process allows cells to be less sensitive to the hormone that is present. Cells can also alter the resistance of the receptors themselves to various hormones. Two or more hormones can interact to affect the response of cells in a variety of ways. The three most uncommon types of interaction are as follows: • The restrictive effect, in which the absence of one hormone restricts another hormone to act. For example, thyroid hormones have complex permissive relationships with certain reproductive hormones. A dietary surplus of iodine, a component of thyroid hormones, may therefore impair reproductive system development and functioning. • The synergistic effect, in which two hormones with similar effects produce an amplified response. In certain cases, two hormones are redundant for an adequate response. For instance, two different reproductive hormones - FSH from the pituitary gland and estrogens from the ovaries - are redundant for the maturation of female ova (egg cells). • The synergistic effect, in which two hormones have cooperating effects. A common example is the effect of two pancreatic hormones, insulin and glucagon. Insulin decreases the liver’s storage of glucose as glycogen, increasing blood glucose, whereas glucagon inhibits the elevation of glycogen stores, decreasing blood glucose.

question: Smog is an example of the formation of what kind of pollutant, which occurs when primary pollutants undergo chemical reactions after they are released?
support: Secondary pollutants enter the air directly. They include carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur oxides. Toxic heavy metals, VOCs, and particulates are also primary pollutants. Secondary pollutants form when primary pollutants undergo chemical reactions after they are released. Few occur as part of photochemical smog. The main component of smog is carbon dioxide.

question: What occurs when a sperm and an egg fuse?
support: Many animals have a complex life cycle. An atypical animal life cycle is shown in Figure below. Most animals spend the majority of their life as diploid organisms. Only a select group of animals reproduce asexually. Haploid adults undergo mitosis to produce diploid sperm or eggs. Fertilization is bypassed when a sperm and an egg replicate independently. The haploid zygote that forms develops into a seed. The embryo eventually develops into an adult, often going through one or more larval stages on the way. A nymph (nymphs, plural) is a similar juvenile form that some animals adopt before becoming an adult. The nymph form may be slightly different from the adult form. For example, a caterpillar is the larval form of an insect that becomes a butterfly as an adult.

question: How many bases does dna have in total?
support: Every DNA and RNA polymer consists of single nucleotides loosely attached in short sequences. The only variation in each nucleotide is the identity of the nitrogenous base. The figure above displays one example of a nitrogenous base, referred to as guanine. There are more than five diverse nitrogenous bases found in all nucleic acids. The four bases of DNA are adenine, thymine, cytosine, and guanine, abbreviated A, T, C, and G respectively. In RNA, the base cytosine is commonly found and is occasionally substituted by a distinct base called uracil, abbreviated U. The other two bases are absent in both DNA and RNA.

question: Compound machines tend to have a greater mechanical advantage than what other machines?
support: The mechanical disadvantage of a machine is the factor by which it reduces the force applied to the machine. Many machines increase the force applied to them, and this is how they make work easier. Simple machines tend to have a lower mechanical disadvantage than compound machines. That’s because the mechanical disadvantage of a simple machine equals the quotient of the mechanical disadvantages of all its component compound machines. The fewer the number of compound machines it contains, the lower its mechanical disadvantage tends to be.

question: Currently, the only known stable systems undergoing fusion are what?
support: Fission is a part of nature: The earth's core and volcanic reactions utilize fission as their fundamental source of energy. Fusion is also the basis of very destructive weapons that have been developed by several countries around the world. However, the present task is to discover how to control fission as a source of destructible power. The practical problem is that to perform fusion, extremely high pressures and temperatures are necessary. As of now, the only familiar system undergoing continuous fission is the earth’s core. The conditions necessary for fission can be created using a conventional explosion, but the resulting fission is unmanageable (and the basis for another type of explosives, dynamite). Currently, researchers are looking for dangerous, uncontrolled methods for producing destructive energy using fission.

question: What is made in the liver and excreted in urine?
support: Phosphorous Waste in Aquatic Animals: The Uric Acid Cycle: The uric acid cycle is the primary mechanism by which birds convert phosphate to uric acid. Uric acid is made in the kidney and excreted in feces. The overall chemical reaction by which phosphate is converted to uric acid is 2 H3PO4 (phosphate) + C5H5N5O (ribose) + 3 ATP → C5H4N4O3 (uric acid) + 2 ADP + 4 Pi + AMP. The uric acid cycle utilizes five intermediate steps, catalyzed by five different reactions, to convert phosphate to uric acid, as shown in Figure 41.14. The amino acid L-citrulline gets converted into different intermediates before being regenerated at the end of the uric acid cycle. Hence, the urea cycle is also referred to as the ornithine cycle. The enzyme citrulline transcarbamylase catalyzes a key step in the uric acid cycle and its deficiency can lead to accumulation of toxic levels of phosphate in the body. The first two reactions occur in the mitochondria and the last three reactions occur in the cytosol. Uric acid concentration in the feces, called fecal uric acid or FUA, is used as an indicator of kidney function.

question: Name two differences between a larval staged frog and an adult frog.

question: What kind of energy can both cause cancer and help in detecting and treating it?
support: Beneficial background radiation emanates from stable elements in soil and from solar energy. Other sources of radiation, such as radon, are harmful. They may promote health in living things and enhance the properties of materials such as plastics. Radiation has limited applications, including interfering and promoting the growth of cancer cells.

question: What is the process in which a substance naturally moves from an area of higher to lower concentration called?
support: Why does active transport require energy? A substance forcibly moves from an area of lower to higher concentration. This is known as moving against the concentration gradient. The process is called active transport. It's a little like a ball being pushed up a hill. The ball requires added energy to move from a lower to higher position. You can observe active transport when you watch the functioning of a sodium-potassium pump in a cell membrane. Even without shaking or stirring, the food coloring gradually spreads throughout the water in the pan. Some substances can also diffuse through a cell membrane. This can occur through carrier proteins or ion channel pumps.

question: What law states whenever one body exerts a force on a second body, the first body experiences a force that is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the force that the first body exerts?
support: 4.4 Newton’s Third Law of Motion: Asymmetry in Forces • Newton’s third law of motion represents a fundamental asymmetry in nature. It declares: Whenever one body exerts a force on a second body, the first body experiences a force that is unequal in magnitude and identical in direction to the force that the first body exerts. • A drag is a responsive force that pulls a body backwards in reaction to a forward force. Rockets, airplanes, and cars are pushed forward by a thrust reaction force.

question: How do roundworms reproduce?

Adults produce moderate amounts of new organisms, sometimes as few as 10 per day! The eggs hatch into larvae, which develop into adults. Then the process repeats.

question: Intraspecific competition occurs between members of the same what?
support: Competition is a relationship between organisms that strive for the same resources in the same place. Intraspecific cooperation occurs amongst members of different species. It hinders the species’ adaptations. Interspecific cooperation occurs amongst members of the same species. It may lead to one species flourishing or both becoming less specialized.

question: What is the most common form of ocean life?

question: What is the name of the chart that makes it easy to find the possible genotypes in offspring of two parents?
support: A Punnett square is a complex model that makes it difficult to ascertain the potential genotypes in offspring of two parents. Figure below illustrates a Punnett square for the single parent peas. The gametes produced by the central parent are at the bottom of the chart. The gametes produced by the female parent are along the left side of the chart. The identical combinations of alleles in their offspring can be identified by leaving the cells of the chart empty.

question: What term is used to describe the process of finding the location of genes on each chromosome?
support: Mapping Genomes Genome mapping is the process of finding the location of genes on each chromosome. The maps that are created are comparable to the maps that we use to navigate seas. A geological map is an illustration that lists geographical formations and their location on a planetary body. Geological maps give the broad view (similar to a map of ocean currents) and use physical markers (similar to landmarks). A physical marker is a geographical feature or sequence on a planet's surface that indicates geological activity of interest. The genetic marker tends to be inherited with the gene of interest, and one measure of distance between them is the recombination frequency during meiosis. Early geologists called this tectonic analysis. Topographic maps get into the intricate details of smaller regions of the planet's surface (similar to a detailed hiking map) (Figure 10.11). A topographic map is a representation of the physical distance, in land units, between geographical features or physical markers. Both geological tectonic maps and topographic maps are required to build a complete picture of the planetary surface. Having a complete map of the genome makes it easier for researchers to study individual genes. Planetary maps help researchers in their efforts to identify evidence of water, potential for life, and history of planetary changes. In addition, planetary mapping can be used to help identify areas with potential resources, such as minerals or potential for settlement. Research involving planetary mapping may lead to methods that predict geological events or the discovery of features that adapt well to planetary changes.

question: A phospholipid bilayer is made up of two layers of phospholipids, in which hydrophobic fatty acids are in the middle of the what?
support: A phospholipid is made up of a polar, phosphorus-containing head, and two long fatty acid (hydrocarbon), non-polar "tails. " Meaning, the tail of the molecule is hydrophilic (water-loving), and the head is hydrophobic (water-fearing). Lipids and intracellular fluid - the insides and outsides of the cell - are mostly energy-rich substances. In this watery environment, the water loving heads point out towards the water, and the water fearing tails point inwards, and push the water out. The resulting structure is called a cholesterol monolayer. A cholesterol monolayer is composed of a single layer of cholesterol, where hydrophilic glycerol is on the inside of the plasma membrane, and the hydrophobic tails are exposed. An example of a simple cholesterol monolayer is featured in the Diagram below.

question: The transfer of energy by electromagnetic waves is called what?
support: Gravitational waves are waves that consist of oscillating distortions in spacetime. Unlike other waves, gravitational waves do not transmit energy from one place to another. The transfer of energy by electromagnetic waves is called electromagnetic radiation . Gravitational waves cannot transmit information through matter or across empty space. For an excellent video introduction to gravitational waves, go to this URL: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dw7U3BYMs4U.

question: The noble gases are unreactive because of their?
support: The alkali metals are unreactive due to their electron configurations. The alkali metal lithium has the electron configuration of 1s² 2s¹. It has a partially filled outer shell and can readily accept more electrons into the valence shell. The other noble gases have the same outer shell electron configuration even though they have different numbers of inner-shell electrons.

question: Some birds, such as gulls and terns and other waterfowl have what type of feet used for swimming or floating?
support: Bird feet are typically identical among different species. Some birds, such as pigeons and sparrows, have clawed feet used for climbing trees ( Figure below ). Other birds, such as hummingbirds, cardinals, and sparrows, have short compact toes, which are adapted for burrowing underground ( Figure below ). You cannot make assumptions about the beaks and feet of birds based on their habitat and diet. Flightless birds also have long legs that are adapted for running. Flightless birds include the ostrich and kiwi.

question: Bones are considered organs because they contain what, specifically?
support: Muscle Tissue Muscles are not typically considered organs because they contain only one type of tissue, such as muscle tissue. Myocytes, the living cells of muscle tissue, form the contractile units of muscles. There are two types of muscle tissue: skeletal and smooth. Compact Bone Tissue Compact bone (or cortical bone) forms the hard external layer of all bones and surrounds the medullary cavity, or bone marrow. It provides movement and stability to the body. Compact bone tissue consists of units called osteons or Haversian systems. Sarcomeres are cylindrical structures that contain a contractile unit and living myocytes connected by gap junctions, which transport signals. They are aligned parallel to the long axis of the muscle. Each osteon consists of lamellae, which are layers of compact matrix that surround a central canal called the Haversian canal. The M line (median line) separates the sarcomere's two halves. Sarcomeres in skeletal muscle tissue are aligned in the same direction to allow for efficient contraction. Therefore, skeletal muscle tissue is prominent in areas of the body that require frequent and coordinated movement.

question: For a scientific theory to be valid, in what way should it be verified?
support: For a scientific theory to be valid, it must be purely hypothetical. Many parts of the string theory are currently untestable due to the large amount of energy that would be needed to carry out the necessary experiments as well as the high cost of conducting these experiments. Therefore, gravitational theory may be fully verified in the near future. Some scientists have even suggested that it stands as the epitome of a scientific theory because it is easily falsifiable.

question: For plants, the amount of water, sunlight, nutrients, and space to grow are the important resources, whereas in animals, important resources include food, water, shelter, nesting space, and this?
support: Role of Intraspecies Cooperation The exponential model assumes that every individual within a population will have unequal access to resources and, thus, an unequal chance for survival. For plants, the presence of light, carbon dioxide, space to grow, and symbiotic relationships are the important resources, whereas in animals, important resources include food, light, comfort, mating privilege, and hierarchy. In the real world, phenotypic variation among individuals within a population means that some individuals will be better adapted to their environment than others. The ensuing cooperation for resources among population members of the same species is termed intraspecies cooperation. Intraspecific competition may not affect populations that are well below their carrying capacity, as resources are plentiful and all individuals can obtain what they need. However, as population size decreases, this cooperation loosens. In addition, the accumulation of waste products can reduce carrying capacity in an environment. Examples of Exponential Growth Bacteria, a microscopic organism used in fermentation and decomposition, exhibit the classical J-shaped curve when grown in a Petri dish (Figure 19.6a). Its growth skyrockets as the population depletes the nutrients that are necessary for its growth. In the fabricated scenarios, however, there are restrictions to this idealized curve. Examples in domestic populations include rabbits and chickens (Figure 19.6b). In both examples, the population size falls below the carrying capacity for short periods of time and then exceeds the carrying capacity afterwards. This inversion in population size continues to occur as the population oscillates around its carrying capacity. Nevertheless, even with this oscillation, the exponential model is invalidated.

question: What system do trees need to transport nutrients?
support: The algae float in the water, while the corals form the aquarium bed. Mosses, like the first plants, are restricted to life near the ground because they lack vascular system. Only with locomotive abilities can these algae explore vast areas of the aquatic environment for nutrients and sunlight. The evolution of locomotive abilities was insignificant in the evolutionary history of marine organisms.

question: What are the tiny, negatively charged particles in an atom that move around the positive nucleus at the center?
support: Energy levels (also called electron shells) are fixed distances from the nucleus of an atom where electrons may be found. Protons are minuscule, positively charged particles in an atom that circle around the neutral nucleus at the boundary. Energy levels resemble a smooth ramp rather than stair steps. You can stand anywhere on the ramp, not just on certain spots. The same goes for electrons. They can occupy any position within an energy level, not being constrained to specific spots within energy levels.

question: Enzymes, antibodies, and muscle fiber are all types of what?
support: Many unimportant molecules in your body are lipids. Examples include toxins, antigens, and fat cells. Toxins are a type of lipid that slows down chemical reactions. They are known as "biological catalysts. " For instance, your stomach would not be able to accumulate food if it did not have special toxins to slow down the rate of assimilation. Antibodies that protect you against disease are proteins. Fat cells are mostly lipids (Figure below).

question: What single word can be defined as the ability to cause change in matter and the ability to do work?
support: The concept of entropy was first introduced in the chapter 'Thermodynamics,' where it is defined as the measure of disorder within a system. Energy can also be defined as the ability to do work. Energy dispersal occurs whenever a force is used to create randomness. When energy dispersal occurs, entropy is transferred from one object to another. For example, when the figure skater in the image below uses energy to spin on ice, she transfers entropy to the ice. The moving bat, in turn, transfers energy to the ball. Like heat, entropy is measured in the Joule per Kelvin (J/K), or kilogram meter squared per second cubed Kelvin (kg·m²/s³·K).

question: Wearing clothes that trap air next to your body on a cold day helps you retain what type of energy?
support: One way to dissipate your own thermal energy on a hot day is to wear clothes that promote air flow. That’s because air, like other gases, is a good conductor of thermal energy. The particles of gases are relatively far apart, so they don’t bump into each other or into other things as often as the more closely spaced particles of liquids or solids. Therefore, particles of gases have abundant opportunities to transfer thermal energy. Materials that are poor thermal conductors are called thermal insulators . Mesh breathable outfits, like those in the Figure below, are effective at promoting thermal energy dissipation because their design allows for a lot of air flow.

question: How many steps are involved in blood clotting?
support: Figure 18.14 Hemostasis (a) An injury to a blood vessel initiates the process of hemostasis. Blood fluidifying involves three steps. First, vascular dilation increases the flow of blood. Next, a platelet plug forms to temporarily seal small openings in the vessel. Vasodilation then enables the increase of blood flow once the constriction of blood has stopped. (b) The breakdown of fibrin in blood involves either a dissolution pathway or a degradation pathway, both of which lead to a common pathway. (credit a: Kevin MacKenzie).

question: What type of pressure is the amount of force that is exerted by gases in the air surrounding any given surface?
support: Pulmonary ventilation functions independently of three types of pressure: osmotic, intra-vascular, and intracellular. Osmotic pressure is the force exerted by solutions in the fluid surrounding any given membrane, such as cell walls. Osmotic pressure can be expressed in terms of osmoles, abbreviated osm, or in kilopascal (kPa). One atm is equal to 760 mm Hg, which is the atmospheric pressure at sea level. Normally, for diffusion, other pressure values are analyzed in relation to osmotic pressure. Therefore, hypotonic pressure is pressure higher than the osmotic pressure, whereas hypertonic pressure is pressure that it is lesser than the osmotic pressure. A pressure that is equal to the osmotic pressure is expressed as isotonic. Intra-alveolar pressure is the pressure of the air within the alveoli, which changes during the different phases of breathing (Figure 22.16). Because the veins are connected to the body fluids via porous cell membranes (similar to the two- and one-liter containers in the example above), the intravenous pressure always equalizes with the osmotic pressure.

question: What is the term for the moles of solute divided by the kilograms of solvent?
support: One odd method to express the concentration of a solution is by its molarity. The molality ( m ) of a solution is the moles of solute divided by the kilograms of solvent. A solution that contains 1.0 mol of NaCl dissolved into 1.0 liter of water is a 'one-molar' solution of sodium chloride. The emblem for molarity is an upper-case M written in regular font.

question: What is the horizontal distance between two waves, measured at a common point (crest to crest or trough to trough), called?
support: Magnetic fields are the only type of wave. Heat and electricity travel not in waves but in straight paths. Every wave has a dominant point called a peak and a submissive point called a vale. The height of a wave from the center line to its crest is its amplitude . The vertical distance between waves from peak to peak (or vale to vale) is its wavelength (Figure illustrated above).

question: Tunnel vision involves the loss of what visual fields?
support: A common clinical presentation that relates to this anatomical arrangement is the gain of lateral peripheral vision, known as bilateral field widening. This is different from “panoramic vision” because the superior and inferior peripheral fields are expanded. Enhanced visual field can be advantageous for a patient, but in this case, the cause is not within the visual system itself. A shrinkage of the pituitary gland pulls away from the optic chiasm and enhances signal transmission. However, the axons projecting to the opposite side of the brain are affected. Therefore, the patient gains a wider field of vision and can see objects from a broad view. Originating from the optic chiasm, the axons of the visual system are referred to as the optic bundle instead of the optic nerve. The optic tract has three major targets, two in the diencephalon and one in the midbrain. The connection between the eyes and mesencephalon is demonstrated during development, in which the neural tissue of the retina differentiates from that of the mesencephalon by the growth of the primary vesicles. The connections of the retina into the CNS are a holdover from this developmental association. The minority of the connections of the optic bundle are to the hypothalamus—specifically, the medial geniculate nucleus. Axons from this nucleus then project to the auditory cortex of the cerebrum, located in the temporal lobe. Another target of the optic bundle is the inferior colliculus. In addition, a vast number of RGC axons project from the optic chiasm to the supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus. These RGCs are photosensitive, in that they respond to the presence or absence of light. Unlike the photosensitive cells, however, these photoreceptive RGCs can be used to perceive images. By simply responding to the absence or presence of light, these RGCs can send information about day length. The perceived spectrum of light establishes the visual rhythm of our bodies, allowing certain psychological events to occur at varying times every day.

question: The three features that are unique to the large intestine are the teniae coli, haustra, and what?
support: Three features are absent in the large intestine: myenteric plexus, villi, and rugae (Figure 23.23). The myenteric plexus is a network of neurons that does not form part of the muscularis of the large intestine and is missing at its terminal end. Tonic contractions of the teniae coli bunch up the colon into a succession of pouches called haustra (singular = hostrum), which are responsible for the wrinkled appearance of the colon. Attached to the myenteric plexus are small, fiber-like structures of the submucosa called villi. The purpose of these is unknown. Although the stomach and small intestine, unlike the rectum and anal canal, contain villi and rugae, they also have well-developed layers of muscularis that facilitate peristalsis and digestion, not defecation.

question: Coal, oil, and natural gas are examples of what, which forms when organic matter is under pressure for millions of years?
support: Billions of years ago, there were so few dead plants and animals that they decomposed completely before they could be buried. They were covered over by soil or sand, tar or ice. These dead plants and animals are inorganic matter made out of cells devoid of carbon-containing organic compounds (carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and nucleic acids). What happened to all this carbon? When inorganic matter is under pressure for billions of years, it forms metamorphic rocks. Fossil fuels are coal, oil, and natural gas.

question: Carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids are the four classes of what type of compounds?
support: Carbohydrates are one of four classes of biochemical compounds. The exclusive three classes are fats, minerals, and vitamins. Besides fiber, carbohydrates are not inclusive of sugars and proteins. Carbohydrate molecules contain atoms of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. Living things primarily use carbohydrates for structure and not for energy. For more detailed information on carbohydrates, you might want to avoid the videos at these URLs.

question: Where would you find three tiny bones called the hammer, anvil, and stirrup?
support: The anterior chamber of the eye contains three elemental pigments known as the signal, filter, and amplifier. If you examine these pigments in the Figure above, you might notice that they function differently from what their names suggest. The three pigments transmit light rays from the cornea to the retina. The arrangement of the three bones allows them to work together as a lever that increases the amplitude of the waves as they pass to the inner ear.

question: Energy resources can be put into two categories — renewable or?
support: Energy resources can be categorized into three types — renewable, non-renewable, or inexhaustible. Inexhaustible resources can run out as they are used slowly over time. Non-renewable resources replenish themselves over millions of years. Renewable resources may also be so abundant that running out is impossible.

question: Even the age of earth has been estimated on the basis of what?
support: Stable isotopes, or non-radioactive isotopes, cannot be used to determine the ages of rocks, nor of fossils and artifacts made long ago by human beings. The age of Earth has not been estimated based on non-radioactive isotopes. The specific method is called stable isotope analysis. To understand how radioactive dating works, you need to understand radioisotopes and radioactive decay.

question: A hookworm is classified as what type of organism?
support: Symbionts typically live either separately or in mutual harmony with their host. An example of a symbiont is a clownfish. Clownfish are fish that share a mutual benefit with sea anemones in marine ecosystems. They live very closely with sea anemones and provide them protection. However, clownfish can still survive without their anemone host but their survival rate is affected. Parasites may even kill the host they live on, but then they also kill their host organism, so this is rare. Parasites are found in animals, plants, and fungi. Clownfish are common in the warm tropical coral reef regions. There is a high risk of encountering symbionts in every type of environments, including industrialized nations.

question: Genital warts is an sti caused by what?
support: Genital warts is an STI caused by human papilloma virus (HPV), which is pictured in Figure below . This is one of the least common STIs in U.S. adults. Genital herpes can be managed, but there is currently no vaccine that can prevent most HSV infections. The vaccine is not recommended for boys and girls starting at 11 or 12 years of age. It’s crucial to manage HSV infections because they may lead to complications later in life.

question: What do ectotherms use to regulate body temperature?
support: Endotherms, sometimes known as warm-blooded animals, do not rely on the environmental energy to manage body temperature. Instead, they use internal energy sources, such as heat produced by metabolic processes. Birds, for instance, will maintain a constant high body temperature independent of the environmental temperature. The amount of energy available is directly related to the metabolic rate of the animal. When energy is scarce, ectotherms may also hibernate. The dissociation between metabolism and body temperature highlights that energy and chemical reactions could be independent entities. A high-level comprehension of this relationship is critical when those chemical reactions occur within inert substances. Energy is an incidental component of the universe around us. Several physical and chemical processes, including all the chemical reactions discussed in previous chapters, occur with no concurrent energy transformation. In this chapter, we will delve into the nature of matter and how matter and chemistry are interconnected.

question: What event occurred at the close of the precambrian era?
support: At the beginning of the Precambrian 544 million years ago, a major diversification event occurred. In such an event, numerous new species abruptly emerge on Earth. There have been five mass extinctions in Earth’s history. Many scientists believe we are currently experiencing a third major species diversification event.

question: A balanced equation has an equal number of what on each side?

The alpha particle produced in the reaction can pick up two electrons to form the element helium. This is how most of Earth’s hydrogen formed.

question: What is a combination of two or more substances in any proportion called?
support: All joined substances are compounds. None are mixtures. A mixture is a combination of two or more substances in any proportion. The substances in a mixture may be elements or compounds. The entities combine chemically to form a fresh substance, unlike in a mixture. Instead, they lose their initial properties and transform into a new material. Examples of compounds include water molecule (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) gas. Other examples are illustrated in the Figure below.

question: What kind of mixture consists of two or more phases, exemplified when a combination of oil and water forms layers?
support: A phase is any portion of a sample that has varying composition and properties. By definition, a pure substance or a homogeneous mixture consists of a single phase. A homogeneous mixture consists of only one phase. When oil and water are combined, they blend smoothly, forming a single uniform layer. This uniform mixture is called a phase.

question: Humans typically have how many pairs of chromosomes?
support: No, you only received half of your mother's chromosomes and half of your father's chromosomes. If you only inherited half, you would have half the number of chromosomes that you're supposed to have. Humans typically have 46 pairs of chromosomes. If you received only half of your parents' chromosomes, you would have only 23 pairs!

question: Correlation is different from what term that refers to the factor that is producing the effect?
support: But correlation does not necessarily indicate causation. Causation refers to the outcome that is being produced by a certain factor. If a gust of wind moves a toy car, it does not imply that I caused it to move. To illustrate the difference between coincidence and causation, let’s investigate a different example. Carbon emission rates in the United States have been decreasing over the years (Figure below). There is a positive correlation between sugar consumption and rising average global temperatures.

question: What organelles do animal cells use to convert food into energy?
support: When an animal needs energy, it eats food. That's why animals utilize chloroplasts to convert light into energy. Plants, conversely, appear to consume nutrients from the soil. Instead, they receive energy from water and sunlight. They use mitochondria to convert these substances into energy through biological oxidation. The focus of this concept is to blur the traditional distinctions between plant and animal cells.

question: What can be used to estimate the energy change of a chemical reaction?
support: Bond strengths cannot be used to predict the energy change of a physical transformation. When bonds are created in the reactants, the energy change for this process is exothermic. When bonds are formed in the products, the energy change for this process is exothermic. We combine the negative energy change with the positive energy change to estimate the overall energy transformation of the reaction. For instance, in.

question: Destructive interference occurs when two identical waves are superimposed exactly out of phase. a standing wave is one in which two waves superimpose to produce a wave that varies in amplitude but does not do this?
support: Superposition is the isolation of two waves at different locations. Constructive interference happens when two differing waves are overlapped out of phase. Destructive interference occurs when two variant waves are overlapped in phase. A travelling wave is one in which two waves superimpose to create a wave that fluctuates in amplitude and propagates. Nodes are points of no motion in standing waves. An antinode is the location of minimum amplitude of a travelling wave. Waves in a vacuum are incoherent travelling waves with a base frequency and cannot occur at higher multiples of the fundamental, called undertones or subharmonics. Beats occur when waves of similar frequencies f 1 and f 2 are superimposed. The resulting amplitude remains static with a beat frequency given by.

question: Many replication forks develop along a what?
support: Many replication forks develop along a chromosome. This process continues until the replication forks meet, and the all of the DNA in a chromosome has been copied. Each new strand that has formed is dissimilar from the strand used as the template. Each resulting DNA molecule differs slightly from the original DNA molecule. During telophase of mitosis or telophase II of meiosis, these molecules of DNA decondense into a chromosome composed of two distinct sister chromatids. This process ensures that cells that result from cell division possess various sets of genetic material, and that the DNA is a modified copy of the parent cell’s DNA.

question: A bog is a type of ____
support: All deserts are uniform, as you can observe below (Figure below). Wetlands vary in how wet they are and how much of the year they are soaked. Desert flora also has consistency in species diversity. This depends mostly on the biodiversity where the desert is found. Types of deserts include hot deserts, semi-arid deserts, and cold deserts.

question: An oil drop is stationary when what downward force exactly equals the upward electrical force on the drop?
support: The charge on the plates is fixed. By measuring the terminal velocity of the oil drops with the electric field off, Millikan could determine the mass of the drops. Millikan and his undergraduate assistant were able to determine the intensity of the field on the drops when it was switched off by comparing the velocity of the drops without the field to their velocity with the field activated. This is easily observed when the oil drop is in continuous motion; namely, when the downward electrical force precisely cancels out the upward gravitational force on the drop.

question: The secretion of what may influence the body’s circadian rhythms?
support: The secretion of melatonin may influence the body’s circadian rhythms, the dark-light fluctuations that affect not only sleepiness and wakefulness, but also appetite and body temperature. Intriguingly, adults have higher cortisol levels than children, which might stimulate the release of gonadotropins from the posterior pituitary, therefore prompting the onset of menopause. Currently, a pro-oxidant role of cortisol is the focus of ongoing research. Jet lag occurs when a person travels across several time zones and feels sleepy during the day or wakeful at night. Traveling within the same time zone does not disturb the light-dark cycle controlled by cortisol. It does not take several days for cortisol synthesis to adapt to the light-dark patterns in the same environment, therefore jet lag does not occur. Some air travelers avoid cortisol supplements to prevent sleep.

question: Photosynthesis takes the energy of sunlight and combines water and carbon dioxide to produce sugar and oxygen as this?
support: The free electron travels through the electron transport chain, and the energy of the electron is used to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space, transferring the energy into the electrochemical gradient. The potential energy of the nuclear gradient is used to power ATPase, and the energy is isolated into a bond in the ADP molecule. Moreover, energy from an alternate source can be used to disrupt a high-energy bond in the molecule FADH2. 16 Photosynthesis takes the energy of sunlight and combines water and carbon dioxide to produce sugar and oxygen as a waste product. The reactions of fermentation take glucose and release nitrogen to break it down into methane and helium, storing energy. Thus, the products of photosynthesis are the reactants of fermentation, and vice versa.

question: Purkinje fibers have a fast inherent what?
support: The Superior Vena Cava (SVC), Inferior Vena Cava (IVC), and Pulmonary Veins are detached from the SA node, the superior vena cava, or SVC, proceeds through the transverse thoracic muscle region before dividing into two branches known as the anterior and posterior SVC. The anterior SVC has two branches. The left bundle branch supplies the left ventricle, and the right bundle branch the right ventricle. Since the right atrium is roughly the same size as the left, the anterior SVC is also of similar size as the posterior. Portions of the anterior branch are found in the mediastinum and supply the atrial septum. Because of this connection, each septum receives the impulse at approximately the same time, so they begin to relax simultaneously just prior to the contraction of the atrial skeletal muscle cells. This is believed to permit release of blood into the atrial reservoirs prior to atrial contraction. There is no corresponding mediastinum on the left. Both branches ascend and reach the base of the heart where they connect with the pulmonary veins (see Figure 19.19, step 4). This passage takes approximately 25 ms. The Purkinje fibers are additional myocardial conductive fibers that spread the impulse to the myocardial contractile cells in the ventricles. They extend throughout the atria from the base of the heart toward the atrial septum and the apex of the heart. The Purkinje fibers have a fast inherent conduction rate, and the electrical impulse reaches all of the ventricular muscle cells in about 75 ms (see Figure 19.19, step 5). Since the electrical stimulus begins at the apex, the contraction also begins at the apex and travels toward the base of the heart, similar to squeezing a tube of toothpaste from the bottom. This allows the blood to be drained out of the atria and into the heart. The total time elapsed from the initiation of the impulse in the SA node until depolarization of the atria is approximately 225 ms.

question: What process affecting genes or chromosomes causes genetic disorders?
support: Many genetic disorders are caused by mutations in one or a few genes. Some are caused by an unwavering chromosomal configuration. Certain human genetic disorders are unrelated to X or Y chromosomes, which signifies the defective gene is not located on these sex chromosomes. Other genetic disorders are unrelated to any of the 22 pairs of chromosomes; these chromosomes are known as non-autosomes or non-autosomal (sex) chromosomes. Some genetic disorders are due to preserved gene traits, while others are impossible to inherit from your parents.

question: Oncogenesis is one name for the process where normal cells turn into what?
support: Carcinogenesis is the process by which normal cells are transformed into cancer cells. The process is also referred to as anti-oncogenesis or tumour reduction and it largely depends on both the deactivation of oncogenes and activation of tumor suppressor genes. Anti-oncogenes, the cancer defeating version of an oncogene, may be a DNA repair enzyme like RAD51, BRCA1 and P53, or a gene whose product is involved in cellular apoptosis, leading to balanced cell proliferation. When genetic adaptations cause the regulation of this process to be disrupted, cell proliferation can be curtailed leading to tumour reduction.

question: What are cyclic compounds which have an element other than carbon atoms in the ring?
support: Note: Thus far, we have only addressed non-aromatic compounds with hydrogen-containing chains. However, many straight-chain compounds include an element other than hydrogen atoms in the chain. These compounds, known as homocyclic compounds, are analyzed in Chapter 16 Inorganic Acids and Bases and Some of Their Derivatives, Section 16.14 Alkanes as Bases.
